boat.name: Dulcibella
boat.full_description:
As 'Susan Ashley' she was the Brook Isle of Wight Lifeboat in the 1930s. She was converted for the film 'The Riddle of the Sands'.

After the film was shot 'Dulcibella' had two or three owners and went to Poole. She was bought by two Germans who painted her black and set off for Hamburg. On the way she was wrecked off the coast where the story 'Riddle of the Sands' is set, the east Frisian Islands. Sadly her crew were lost.

The book 'Riddle of the Sands' was written by Erskine Childers in 1903 and is the first espionage story. it is set in the East Frisian Islands and centres around two English sailors who uncover a plot by the Germans to invade Britain through the Wash, at that time unprotected by the British Navy.

Erskine Childers wrote the book to advocate the preparedness for war as the best form of defence. He was a famous sailor, a member of the Royal Cruising Club having won a number of their trophies. His yacht 'Asgard' was a wedding present from his wife's family. In 1914 he used her for gun running into Ireland and was eventually shot by the Free Irish. Read more about this on 'Sailing by'.

Childers' boat 'Asgard' has been restored and is in a museum in Dublin. The film was produced by Worldmark Productions Ltd. Laurent Giles and Partners designed the conversion of the 'Susan Ashley', giving her a centreboard to make her suitable for sailing in shallow and deep waters. Spencer's were responsible for the spars and J Rawlings of 'G' Sailmakers made the sails.
boat.construction_details: Diagonal 2 skins of teak. Counter, a centreboard and a gaff yawl rig were added when she was converted to the Dulcibella.
boat.short_description: Susan Ashley, the Brook Isle of Wight lifeboat was converted by Laurent Giles and Partners into the Dulcibella for the film Riddle of the Sands in 1978.
